name: 🍽️ Cooking Unit
description: This is a unit about cooking
lessons[0].title: Cooking Vocabulary
lessons[1].title: What is a Recipe
lessons[0].description: In this lesson, you’ll learn about different cooking words that help us talk about food and meals! Knowing these words will make it easier to talk about what we eat each day and understand more about what goes into making yummy meals.
lessons[1].description: In this lesson, you’ll learn what a recipe is and why it’s helpful! A recipe is like a special guide that shows us how to make delicious foods. It tells us what ingredients we need and gives us steps to follow so our food turns out just right. Recipes make cooking fun and easy!
lessons[0].instruction: Look at each picture and learn the new word. Each flashcard shows a type of food or meal we enjoy! Try saying each word out loud and think of a time when you've had that food. Have fun learning about all the delicious foods we eat!
lessons[1].instruction: Look at the picture to see an example of a recipe. Think about how each recipe has a list of ingredients and steps to follow. Imagine if you were making something yummy—this recipe would tell you exactly what to do! Try to remember what recipes do and how they help us cook.
lessons[0].lesson_content[0].description: A meal is when we sit down to eat yummy food. Meals give us energy and help us grow strong! We have meals at different times of the day, like breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Each meal is a time to enjoy tasty food with family or friends!

Breakfast is the very first meal we eat in the morning after we wake up. It can include foods like cereal, toast, eggs, or even fruit! Breakfast gives us the energy we need to start our day and feel strong and ready for school or playtime.

Lunch is the meal we have around the middle of the day, usually after we’ve been busy in the morning. We might have a sandwich, some veggies, or even soup. Lunch helps keep us full of energy for the rest of the afternoon!

Dinner is the meal we eat in the evening, often with our family. It’s a special time to talk about our day and enjoy yummy food like pasta, rice, or maybe even some vegetables. Dinner is the last meal before bedtime and fills us up for the night.

Cake is a sweet, soft treat that we often enjoy on special days like birthdays! Cake is usually made with ingredients like flour, sugar, and eggs, and it can come in many flavors like chocolate or vanilla. Sometimes, it even has frosting on top!

Bread is a soft and fluffy food made from flour, water, and yeast. We eat bread in many ways, like in sandwiches or toast, or just plain! It’s delicious and can be a part of breakfast, lunch, or dinner. Bread has a nice, chewy texture that makes it fun to eat!

An egg is a round food that comes from chickens. It’s packed with good stuff that helps us grow! Eggs can be cooked in many ways, like scrambled, boiled, or fried, and we often eat them for breakfast. They’re super tasty and very healthy!

Rice is a small, white grain that becomes soft and fluffy when cooked. It’s a popular food around the world and goes well with many dishes! You might have rice with veggies, meat, or even on its own. It’s filling, tasty, and fun to eat with a spoon or fork!
exercises[0].title: Translate
exercises[1].title: Synonyms
exercises[2].title: Can Haikus Speak
exercises[3].title: Complete the Haiku
exercises[4].title: Match the text
exercises[1].description: In this exercise you will learn about synonyms
exercises[2].description: In this lesson, you’ll explore fun and creative haikus about food! A haiku is a short poem that helps us picture something special, like a delicious meal. Each haiku in this lesson describes a different type of food. Get ready to use your imagination and think about the tastes, smells, and feelings these foods bring!
exercises[3].description: In this lesson, you’ll get to create your own food-inspired haikus by filling in the missing words! Haikus are short poems that use just a few words to paint a picture or describe a feeling. You’ll help complete each haiku with words that make it sound yummy and fun.
exercises[4].description: In this exercise, you’ll have fun matching people with the meals they made or ate. Each person has prepared something different, and your job is to figure out who made or ate what. Let’s see how well you can match them!
exercises[0].instruction: Read the text and try to write down what you understood in Thai.
exercises[1].instruction: Read the text and for each word, find the synonym (word with the same meaning) form the text.
exercises[2].instruction: Read each haiku carefully and imagine the food it describes. After reading, answer the questions by thinking about your own favorite flavors and foods! This is your chance to share what you love about these foods and get creative with your answers.
exercises[3].instruction: Look at each haiku and think about words that would make sense in the blanks. Use words that describe food, taste, or smell. Imagine you’re writing about your favorite foods and how they look, taste, and smell. Have fun creating your own version of each haiku!
exercises[4].instruction: Read each person’s description of what they ate or cooked. Then, drag and drop the correct description to match the person with their food. Take your time and think about what each person says—it’s like solving a little puzzle!
exercises[0].exercise_content[0].context:
Tom is hungry. He walks to the kitchen and gets some eggs. He takes some oil and puts a pan on the stove. Next, he turns on the heat and pours the oil into the pan. He cracks the eggs into a bowl, mixes them, and then pours them into the hot pan. He waits while the eggs cook.
They cook for two minutes.
Next, Tom puts the eggs on a plate and places the plate on the dining room table. Tom feels happy because he cooked eggs. He sits down in the big wooden chair, and eats the eggs with a spoon. They are good.
He washes the plate with dishwashing soap, then washes the pan. He wets a sponge and finally cleans the table.
exercises[1].exercise_content[0].context: Tom is excited to cook his favorite recipe. He starts by getting a fresh set of vegetables from the market. He carefully washes them to make sure they are clean. Tom uses a sharp knife to chop the vegetables into small pieces. He heats some oil in a pan until it is hot. Then, he adds the vegetables and mixes them until they are tender. After cooking, Tom puts the vegetables on a plate. The meal looks very appealing, and Tom feels happy with his delicious dish.
exercises[2].exercise_content[0].context: Rice in a bowl shines,\nSoy sauce dances with chopsticks,\nWhat do you taste first?
exercises[2].exercise_content[1].context: Pizza fresh and hot,\nCheese melts like the warmest hug,\nWhat's your favorite slice?
exercises[2].exercise_content[0].questio: When you eat rice, do you like to add anything special?
exercises[2].exercise_content[1].questio: If you could design a pizza, what toppings would you put on it?

name: 🎾 ️Sports Unit
description: This is a unit about sports
lessons[0].title: Sports Flashcards
lessons[1].title: Understanding Verbs for Different Types of Sports and Activities
lessons[0].description: Learn about different sports activities with these flashcards.
lessons[1].description: Learn which verbs to use with different types of sports and activities. In this lesson, you will review and apply the verbs 'play,' 'go,' and 'do' in the present simple tense.
lessons[0].instruction: Review each flashcard to familiarize yourself with various sports.
lessons[1].instruction: Review the rules for choosing the correct verb based on the type of activity. Use 'play' for team sports, 'go' for activities ending in -ing, and 'do' for individual activities. Then, try applying these rules to your own examples.
lessons[0].lesson_content[0].description: A popular sport involving kicking a ball to score goals.
A team sport where players try to shoot a ball into the opponent's basket.
A racquet sport played by hitting a ball back and forth across a net.
A game where players hit a ball over a net using their hands.
An activity that involves moving through water by swimming strokes.
A sport where individuals or teams compete by running various distances.
An activity involving riding a bicycle, often for sport or recreation.
A sport where players hit a ball with a bat to score runs.

exercises[0].exercise_content[0].context: In this sport, players use a racket to hit a small ball over a net. You can play it with two or four people. It is played on a court, and the goal is to make the ball land in the other player’s side.
exercises[0].exercise_content[1].context: This sport is played indoors on a court. Two teams try to hit a ball over a high net using only their hands. Players work together to keep the ball in the air and make it land in the other team’s court.
exercises[0].exercise_content[2].context: This sport is played on a field with two teams. Each team has eleven players. They kick a ball and try to score goals by putting the ball into the other team’s net. Players cannot touch the ball with their hands, except the goalkeeper.
exercises[0].exercise_content[3].context: In this winter sport, athletes race down a snowy hill on skis. The goal is to be the fastest to reach the bottom. Skiers need good balance and control to make quick turns on the snow.
exercises[0].exercise_content[4].context: In this sport, players use paddles to hit a small ball on a table. It is a very fast game, and players need quick reflexes. The ball has to bounce on the table, and players try to make it difficult for the other player to return the ball.
exercises[0].exercise_content[5].context: This sport is done on a court, where players use their hands to bounce a ball and try to throw it into a basket. Teams score points by making the ball go through the other team’s hoop.
exercises[0].exercise_content[6].context: This is a water sport where you swim across a pool as fast as you can. There are different styles, like freestyle or butterfly. You can swim in races by yourself or as part of a team, trying to finish first.
exercises[0].exercise_content[7].context: In this sport, people climb high mountains or tall indoor walls. They use ropes to keep themselves safe. It’s a challenging activity, and it requires strength, balance, and good planning.
exercises[4].exercise_content[0].context: In this activity, participants navigate through rugged terrain, often including trails, hills, or mountains. It’s usually done with a backpack, water, and good hiking shoes. The goal is to enjoy nature and reach scenic viewpoints.
exercises[4].exercise_content[1].context: This adventure activity involves exploring caves, often underground. Participants use helmets, lights, and sometimes ropes to move through narrow passages and underground formations. It requires a sense of adventure and comfort in tight spaces.
exercises[4].exercise_content[2].context: In this activity, participants use a paddle to navigate down a river with rapids. The water is rough, and it requires teamwork, strength, and skill to stay in control. The goal is to safely make it to the end of the river stretch.
exercises[4].exercise_content[3].context: This activity involves reaching the summit of mountains or tall cliffs. It requires climbing gear such as ropes, harnesses, and helmets. Physical strength, endurance, and skill are essential to succeed.
exercises[4].exercise_content[4].context: In this underwater activity, participants use an air tank and breathing apparatus to explore marine life and underwater landscapes. Clear waters and colorful coral reefs are popular destinations for this adventure.
exercises[4].exercise_content[5].context: This is a desert-based activity where participants use boards to slide down large sand dunes. Similar to snowboarding, it requires balance and skill to stay upright as you slide down.
exercises[4].exercise_content[6].context: In this popular coastal activity, participants stand or sit on boards to catch waves. Balance and timing are essential to ride the waves successfully and enjoy the thrill.
exercises[5].exercise_content[0].context: In this sport, players use rackets to hit a shuttlecock over a net. It’s played indoors or outdoors and requires quick reflexes and agility. It’s typically played with two or four players.
exercises[5].exercise_content[1].context: This sport involves a team passing a disc, aiming to score by catching it in the opponent’s end zone. It requires teamwork, running, and throwing skills. It's a popular outdoor activity.
exercises[5].exercise_content[2].context: This fast-paced water sport involves two teams trying to score by throwing a ball into the opposing team’s net. Players swim across the pool to pass, shoot, and defend. It’s intense and requires endurance.
exercises[5].exercise_content[3].context: In this sport, athletes use a small board with wheels to perform tricks, balance, and ride. It often takes place in skate parks or on streets and requires creativity and skill.
exercises[5].exercise_content[4].context: This sport involves jumping from a plane and freefalling before opening a parachute. Participants experience a rush of adrenaline as they control their descent. Safety gear and a licensed instructor are required.
exercises[5].exercise_content[5].context: In this sport, players wear helmets and protective gear as they move a small rubber puck across the ice. Teams compete to shoot the puck into the opponent’s goal using sticks.
exercises[5].exercise_content[6].context: This sport is played on a large court, where players use rackets to hit a ball over a net. It can be played as singles or doubles and requires speed, precision, and stamina.
exercises[5].exercise_content[7].context: In this sport, participants race in lightweight boats powered by oars. It can be done solo or in teams, and takes place on rivers, lakes, or oceans. Timing, rhythm, and strength are key to success.
exercises[6].exercise_content[0].context: When a soccer player kicks the ball, it moves because of a force. This science studies forces, movement, and how things speed up or slow down.
exercises[6].exercise_content[1].context: This technology helps coaches record games so players can watch and learn from their mistakes. It’s used to make videos of soccer games, basketball games, and more.
exercises[6].exercise_content[2].context: In sports, athletes need to stay strong and healthy. Eating fruits, vegetables, and proteins like chicken and beans helps them get energy and build muscle.
exercises[6].exercise_content[3].context: When runners run fast, the wind pushes against them. This is a type of force that tries to slow them down. Scientists study it to help athletes move better.
exercises[6].exercise_content[4].context: Athletes need strong muscles and good bones to do their best. This science studies muscles, bones, and how they help us move in sports.
exercises[6].exercise_content[5].context: In team sports like soccer or basketball, coaches use a whiteboard to show players where to go and what to do. It helps them plan their next moves.
exercises[6].exercise_content[6].context: This device can tell how fast a runner or cyclist is going. It helps athletes track their speed during training.
exercises[6].exercise_content[7].context: To stay safe, athletes wear special clothes and gear like helmets, knee pads, and gloves. This equipment protects them from injuries.

name: 📍 ️Places
lessons[0].title: Places Vocabulary
lessons[1].title: Limericks
lessons[0].description: Learn the names and functions of different places we encounter in daily life. This flashcard set introduces vocabulary for common locations like parks, schools, hospitals, and more, each with an image, title, and description.
lessons[1].description: This lesson presents a visual learning experience with an image. Use the image to observe details and answer related questions, enhancing observational skills.
lessons[0].instruction: Review each flashcard to learn the vocabulary for various places. Pay attention to the images, names, and descriptions to understand where each place is and what it's used for. Try to remember the details and think of examples of each place in your own life.
lessons[1].instruction: Study the image carefully and think about the elements you see. Reflect on what each part might represent or mean.
lessons[0].lesson_content[0].description: A green, outdoor area with trees, grass, and pathways, often used for relaxation, exercise, and family gatherings.
A place where students go to learn, often with classrooms, teachers, and various subjects being taught.
A medical facility where doctors and nurses care for people who are sick or injured, equipped with specialized medical equipment.
A place where people live, usually consisting of rooms for sleeping, eating, and relaxation, and providing comfort and security.
A location where people go to eat meals prepared by chefs, often offering a variety of food and drinks.
A large store that sells a wide range of food and household items, with aisles and sections for different types of products.
A place where movies are shown on a big screen, often with comfortable seating and a concession stand for snacks.
An establishment that provides temporary lodging for travelers, with rooms, and often additional services like dining and housekeeping.

name: ☁️ ️Weather and Seasons
description: This is about weather and seasons
lessons[0].title: Weather and season vocabulary
lessons[1].title: Limericks and Haikus
lessons[0].description: Learn about different types of weather and seasons through these flashcards. Each card introduces key vocabulary with images and descriptions to help you understand the unique features of each season and weather type.
lessons[1].description: Explore the differences between two popular types of poetry: limericks and haikus. This image shows examples of each form and provides a breakdown of their unique structures. Limericks are five-line poems with a playful rhythm and rhyme, while haikus are three-line poems that focus on nature and follow a 5-7-5 syllable pattern. Notice the seasonal themes in each poem and how the rhythm or syllable count affects the mood and flow.
lessons[0].instruction: Review each flashcard to learn about various types of weather and seasons. Read the description, observe the image, and try to memorize the vocabulary. Use this knowledge to talk about the weather or describe the seasons.
lessons[1].instruction: Look at the examples of limericks and haikus in this image. A limerick has five lines with a specific rhyme scheme (AABBA) and a playful, bouncy rhythm. The haiku, on the other hand, has three lines and focuses on capturing a moment in nature using a 5-7-5 syllable structure. Pay attention to how each form uses structure and syllables differently to create a unique feel. Think about how syllables, rhythm, and rhyme can make each type of poem feel different as you read them aloud.
lessons[0].lesson_content[0].description: Spring is the season when flowers start to bloom, and the weather becomes warmer and sunnier. Trees and plants come to life, and people enjoy outdoor activities.
Summer is the hottest season of the year, with long, sunny days. It's a popular time for beach trips, swimming, and vacations as people enjoy the warm weather.
Autumn, also known as fall, is the season when leaves change color and fall from trees. The weather becomes cooler, and many people enjoy the beautiful scenery.
Winter is the coldest season, often bringing snow and frosty weather. People celebrate holidays, drink hot chocolate, and enjoy indoor activities to stay warm.
Sunny weather means the sun is shining brightly, with clear skies and no clouds. It's a perfect day for outdoor activities like picnics and sports.
Rainy weather brings clouds and rain, sometimes with thunderstorms. People use umbrellas and raincoats to stay dry while enjoying the sound of raindrops.
Snowy weather means snow is falling, covering everything in a blanket of white. People enjoy activities like building snowmen, skiing, and snowball fights.
Windy weather is when the wind is blowing strongly. It can make the air feel colder, and people often bundle up or find shelter from the breeze.

exercises[3].description: This exercise combines the creativity of poetry with the themes of different seasons. Students will fill in the blanks to complete a limerick and a haiku, using words that fit the seasonal context. This activity helps reinforce vocabulary and understanding of poetic forms.

name: 🏫 ️School
description: This is a unit about school
lessons[0].title: Classroom Vocabulary Flashcards
lessons[0].description: This lesson will help you learn and remember the names and descriptions of common items found in a classroom. By using flashcards with images, titles, and detailed descriptions, you will enhance your vocabulary and understanding of these objects.
lessons[0].instruction: Click on each flashcard to see the name of the item. Try to remember the name and description of each item to enhance your vocabulary.
lessons[0].lesson_content[0].description: The person who helps students learn and understand new things. They teach lessons, answer questions, and guide students through their studies.
The person who learns new things in the class. They listen to the teacher, do their homework, and try to understand new ideas.
The room where students and teachers come together to learn. It has desks, chairs, a blackboard, and many other tools for learning.
A table where students can write, read, and do their work. It often has space for books, notebooks, and other school supplies.
A seat where students sit while they are learning. It is usually placed next to a desk and helps students stay comfortable during lessons.
A large board where teachers write lessons and draw pictures. It can be used to explain new ideas and show important information to the whole class.
A book full of stories or information that students read to learn. It can be about many different topics and helps students understand the world better.
exercises[0].title: Day at my School
exercises[1].title: Describe the next object
exercises[2].title: Complete the Limerick and Haiku
exercises[3].title: Exploring My School Adventure
exercises[4].title: Sports Day at My School
exercises[5].title: A Day at My Science-Focused School
exercises[0].description:
My school is big and has many different places for us to learn and have fun. Every morning, I arrive at school at 8:00. The first thing I do is go to my classroom, where my teacher, Mr. Green, waits for us. We have many subjects, like Math, English, Science, and Art. My favorite subject is Art because I love to draw and paint.

During the day, we also go to the library. The library is full of books about animals, space, history, and more. I like to read books about animals. Sometimes, the librarian reads us a story.

At break time, my friends and I go to the playground. We play games like tag, hopscotch, and soccer. After break, we go to the gym for Physical Education. We do exercises and sometimes play basketball.

Our school day ends at 3:00 in the afternoon. I pack my bag, say goodbye to my friends and teacher, and go home. I like my school because I can learn new things and play with my friends.
exercises[1].description: Describe each object in the pictures below. Try to use detailed descriptions and explain what each item is used for.
exercises[2].description: In this exercise, you will complete the lines of a Limerick and a Haiku by filling in the blanks with appropriate words.
exercises[3].description:
My school is like a world of discovery! There are many exciting places to explore and learn new things. Every morning, I arrive at school at 8:00. The first stop on my adventure is the classroom, where my teacher, Mr. Green, waits to guide us through a new day. We explore many subjects like Math, Science, English, and Art. My favorite subject is Art because it lets me explore my creativity through drawing and painting.

During the day, we also venture to the library. The library is a treasure chest full of books about animals, space, history, and more. I love to explore books about animals. Sometimes, the librarian takes us on a storytelling adventure.

At break time, my friends and I head to the playground. We embark on games like tag, hopscotch, and soccer. After break, we go to the gym for Physical Education, where we discover new ways to stay active. Sometimes, we even play basketball.

Our school day ends at 3:00 in the afternoon. I pack my bag, say goodbye to my friends and teacher, and head home, ready for tomorrow's adventure. I love my school because it’s a place full of discoveries and fun with my friends.
exercises[4].description:
Our school is big, and we have lots of space for sports and physical activities. Every morning, I arrive at school at 8:00. The first thing I do is head to my classroom where my teacher, Mr. Green, is waiting for us. We have many subjects like Math, English, Science, and Physical Education. My favorite subject is Physical Education because I love to run, jump, and play sports.

During the day, we also go to the gym. In gym class, we play sports like basketball, soccer, and sometimes we race each other. I love playing soccer with my friends. Sometimes, we go to the playground, where we play tag or have races.

At lunch, my friends and I like to play in the field. We sometimes play football or practice basketball. After lunch, we return to the gym for more physical activities. We do stretching exercises and play different sports games. It’s always fun and helps me feel strong and healthy.

Our school day ends at 3:00 PM. I pack my bag, say goodbye to my friends and teacher, and head home. I love my school because I get to play sports and learn new things every day!
exercises[5].description:
Our school is big and has amazing places where we learn about science and technology. Every morning, I arrive at school at 8:00. The first thing I do is head to my classroom, where my teacher, Mr. Green, is waiting for us. We have many subjects like Math, English, Science, and Computer Studies. My favorite subject is Science because I love learning about space, animals, and how things work.

During the day, we also go to the science lab. The science lab is full of cool tools like microscopes and test tubes. I like to experiment with different chemicals and learn about the world around me. Sometimes, we use computers to do experiments or learn about new technology.

At break time, my friends and I go to the playground, but sometimes we also talk about cool inventions or science experiments we've seen. After break, we go to the computer lab where we learn how to code and build small projects using technology.

Our school day ends at 3:00 PM. I pack my bag, say goodbye to my friends and teacher, and go home. I love my school because I get to learn about the latest science discoveries and technology advancements every day!

name: 🐯 Animals
description: This is a unit about animals
lessons[0].title: Animals Vocabulary
lessons[0].description: In this lesson, you will learn about different animals that live in the world! Knowing these animals, you will find out how smart and curious they can be, where they live and how they are.
lessons[0].instruction: Look at each picture and learn the new word. Each flashcard shows a different animal. Try to say each word out loud and enjoy the cute and weird animals.
lessons[0].lesson_content[0].description: Octopuses are sea animals famous for their rounded bodies, bulging eyes, and eight long arms. They live in all the world’s oceans but are especially abundant in warm, tropical waters. Octopuses, like their cousin, the squid, are often considered “monsters of the deep,” though some species, or types, occupy relatively shallow waters.
Elephants, descendants of mammoths, are the largest land animals in the world, being able to grow up to 3 meters tall. They’re known for their long trunk, tusks, big floppy ears and wrinkly skin.

Bears are large animals with short tails that mainly live in the Americas, Asia, and Europe. They are the largest of the carnivores, or flesh-eating land mammals. However, besides the meat-eating polar bears and the bamboo-eating panda bears, most bears are omnivorous (eating both plant and animal matter).

Whales are large animals that live in water. Whales may look like fishes, but they are mammals. They breathe air and produce milk for their young. Whales make up an order, or large group of animals, called Cetacea.
a bird with a plump body, small head, and short legs. Some kinds of pigeons are also called rock doves.\nWe sat on a park bench and tossed bits of cookie to the pigeons.

Dolphins look like large fish, but they are actually small whales. They belong to a family that includes the common dolphin as well as killer whales, or orcas. Like all whales and other mammals, they breathe through lungs instead of gills and give birth to live young.

Swans are waterbirds with heavy bodies and long necks. They swim gracefully, seeming to glide across the water. They are also strong fliers. Along with ducks and geese, swans belong to a family of birds called waterfowl in North America and wildfowl in Europe.

Deer are mammals that are noted for having two large and two small hooves (a hard covering to protect the toes) on each foot. The males of most species of deer and the females of one species have bony growths called antlers, which they shed each year.

exercises[0].description: There are many animals in the world and all of them are different and special. Some can be scary and some can be cute, but all of them are very cool.
exercises[1].description: A riddle is a type of puzzle or question that uses clever wording to make you think and figure out the answer. It usually describes something in a tricky or indirect way, making you guess what it is. Riddles are often fun and challenge your brain to solve them!
exercises[2].description: Bears are large mammals with thick fur, strong claws, and a great sense of smell. They live in forests, mountains, and arctic regions, and eat a variety of foods like plants, fish, and berries. Would you like to learn more about them?
exercises[3].description: A mythical animal is a creature from stories and legends that doesn’t exist in real life. These animals, like dragons, unicorns, and phoenixes, often have special powers or unique traits and are found in myths from different cultures around the world.

The elephants, on the other hand, are very massive and slow. Despite their size, they are calm creatures.

At the front, it features a fierce head with sharp teeth and glowing eyes. Rising from its back is another head, this one resembling a smaller, horned creature. Its tail is long and snake-like, often depicted with scales that glisten in shades of green and black. It is a mix of strength and ferocity.

name: 🧍 Human Body
description: This is a unit about human body
lessons[0].title: Body Vocabulary
lessons[0].description: In this lesson, you will learn about different body parts that help us talk about the human body and health.
lessons[0].instruction: Look at each picture and learn the new word. Each flashcard shows a part of our body! Try saying each word out loud.
lessons[0].lesson_content[0].description: A tooth is a hard, white bone in your mouth that helps you chew food. We have different types of teeth, like incisors and molars, that have unique shapes for biting, tearing, or grinding food.

The tongue is a strong, flexible muscle in your mouth that helps with tasting, chewing, and swallowing food. It has tiny bumps called taste buds that detect flavors like sweet, salty, sour, and bitter. The tongue also helps us speak clearly by shaping sounds into words.

Lips are soft, flexible edges of the mouth that help us eat, speak, and express emotions. They protect the mouth and are sensitive, allowing us to feel textures and temperatures. Lips also play a big role in forming sounds when we talk.

The thumb is the short, thick finger on the side of your hand that helps with gripping and holding objects. Unlike other fingers, it can move in different directions, allowing us to pinch and grab things with precision. The thumb is essential for many tasks, like writing, tying shoelaces, and using tools.

The chest is the upper part of the body, located between the neck and the stomach. It protects important organs like the heart and lungs, which are surrounded by the ribcage. Muscles in the chest also help with breathing and arm movements.

The elbow is the joint in the middle of your arm that connects the upper arm to the forearm. It allows your arm to bend and straighten, helping you perform actions like lifting, throwing, and reaching. The elbow works with muscles and bones to give your arm flexibility and strength.

The knee is the joint in the middle of your leg that connects the thigh to the lower leg. It allows your leg to bend and straighten, making movements like walking, running, and jumping possible. The knee joint is supported by strong ligaments and muscles, giving stability and strength to your leg.

Toes are the small digits at the front of your feet that help with balance and movement. They work together to support your weight, especially when walking, running, or standing on uneven surfaces. Each toe has joints that allow for flexibility and stability in your step.

exercises[0].exercise_content[0].context: The heart is a very important organ. It pumps blood around the body. The heart is in the chest, between the lungs. The heart has four parts called chambers. They are the right atrium, right ventricle, left atrium, and left ventricle. Blood comes into the heart through veins and goes out through arteries. The heart beats about 70 times every minute. It helps give oxygen and food to the body and takes away waste.

name: 🚗 Transportation
description: This is a unit about transportation
lessons[0].title: Transportation Flashcards
lessons[1].title: Map of the city and directions
lessons[0].description: In this lesson, you will learn about transportation. Knowing these ways of transportation will show you how to move around the city, your country and the world!
lessons[1].description: Transportation is how people and goods move from one place to another, using things like cars, trains, planes, and boats. Today, we'll explore different types of transportation, how they work, and why they’re important for connecting our world.
lessons[0].instruction: Look at each picture and learn the new word. Each flashcard shows a different vehicle or road-related vocabulary. Try to say each word out loud and enjoy the ride!\n
lessons[1].instruction: Look at the map and try to solve the questions on the right with your classmates. Will you arrive fast and safely to the right locations?
lessons[0].lesson_content[0].description: A boat is a watercraft designed to float and move on water, used for transporting people or goods. Boats come in various sizes and shapes, from small rowboats to large ships, and can be powered by paddles, sails, or engines. They’re used for activities like fishing, travel, and recreation on rivers, lakes, and oceans.

An airplane is a large, powerful vehicle designed to fly through the air, carrying people and cargo over long distances. It has wings to lift it off the ground and engines that provide thrust to move it forward. Airplanes are used for travel, transport, and connecting people around the world quickly.

A train is a long vehicle that runs on tracks, used to transport people or goods across distances on land. It’s made up of connected cars pulled by a powerful engine and travels through cities, countryside, or even underground. Trains are an efficient way to move many passengers or heavy loads at once.

A bicycle is a human-powered vehicle with two wheels, pedals, and handlebars for steering. Riding a bike involves pedaling to move forward and balancing to stay upright. Bicycles are used for exercise, transportation, and fun, and they’re an eco-friendly way to get around.

A truck is a large, powerful vehicle designed to carry heavy loads over long distances. It has a strong engine and a big cargo area in the back for transporting goods like furniture, food, or building materials. Trucks are essential for delivering supplies and materials across cities and countries.

Traffic refers to the movement of vehicles, bicycles, and pedestrians on roads, often creating busy or crowded conditions. It includes cars, buses, trucks, and other forms of transportation, all following rules to keep roads safe and organized. Traffic can sometimes cause delays, especially in cities during rush hours.

A road is a paved or prepared path that allows vehicles, bicycles, and pedestrians to travel from one place to another. Roads connect cities, towns, and neighborhoods, and they are often marked with lines and signs to guide safe movement. Roads can vary from small neighborhood streets to large highways.

A station is a designated place where people can board or get off vehicles like trains, buses, or subways. Stations often have waiting areas, ticket counters, and information signs to help travelers. They serve as central points in a transportation system, connecting different routes and destinations.
